text:
Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: Alex Margaret Goodhorns

Present Address: Dunlop

Pioneer Address: Mount Green

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1906

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? (5)

How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? (when we could)

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? (monthly Sundays)

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? (many times invited & when we liked to drop in)

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? (in the afternoon? Sometimes to dinner)

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? (yes all were welcomed any time)

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) (no we were always very welcome - no excuse used)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? (tea & cake)

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? (we usually all went those days we sometimes had a house full)

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? (yes)

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred. (we had quilting bees - a building and house for a neighbor who had his frame house burned)

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. (yes we had Dances in the homes square dances too mostly some what games played)

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. (not so much & not at all now except card parties)

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? (just fell like it)
1. In the first ten years, how many houses were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? (5)

2. How many of these were bachelor's homes? (3)

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? (Weekly)

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? (Yes)

What time of the day did you go? - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? (Afternoon)

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? (Yes)

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take patrickus" used, or was some other expression common?) (No, the meal was always very welcome)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? (Tea or Cake)

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "lock after the places"? (Not usually all went, when there were guests, and the house was crowded)

6. Did you ever have "teas," when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? (Yes)

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "teas" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe. (We never had dances in the pioneer days, but we did have parties.)

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. (Yes)

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? (Yes)
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

He used them for hall purposes and had our school Christmas tree.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community purposes inside and outside. (Include also the school district, taxes, etc.)

9. When was your first community hall built? What material was it made of? How large was it?

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in houses, school houses or halls (as referred to in Question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Was there card playing for prizes? What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? 

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Yes.

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc. We just had them once. Newly wed were invited in & treated royally to the best they had.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

We often had dancing games & dinner ball games & races, and etc.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? The grain growers association.

Give the date and reason for it being organized. 1910 To get justice for farmers.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Yes.

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization. 1910

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it? Half.

How many women belonged? All the wives. How often did it meet? Once every 2 weeks.

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization? Picnics & suppers.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? Not then.

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
12. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? If so, when was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

13. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community? Give the date and reason for its being organized.

14. Has there been an organization in your community that has been active in promoting the welfare of the community?

15. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Association in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

16. Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belong to the association?

17. How many women belonged to the association? How often did it meet? What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was central in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaires for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

There was none in our district.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

By Social Suppers

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? In School House

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? No

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides? Missionary

What were the slides about? Foreign Land

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Marbles Kite Ball

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? Both
16. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1934, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes. Who belonged (men, women, young people), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centered in the town or village and included the surrounding communities? (If the church was in the church questionnaires the organizations connected with the church so they need not be included here).

There was only one church.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

School house

18. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

School house

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? No

Describe telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), what they were, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

That were the slides about:

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Mumblety peg ball.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   Skating - yes or no.

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?  
   Checkers - Happy families - Authors old made - dominoes.

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  
   The whole family.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
   We took times for games.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.  
   Yes very much - Snaring gophers - rabbits - finding arrow heads.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.  
   1912.

26. Who organized it?  
   From groups.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
   School district neighborhood.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?  
   Yes.

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?  
   1910.

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
   Yes - races - ball games mostly - country dances.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
   We all spread our table cloths & placed our food on it and all visited & passed our goods around.

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
   Of everything good, we had just grand dinner, cold & warm, hot tea coffee and lemonade.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
   About 10 a.m. started till 5:30 p.m., in time to get home to do chores.
23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone unusually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, reptiles or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PIONICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?

Give year and month, if possible.

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating—was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

Well we just enjoyed meeting the neighbors and admiring the babies or watching them all during games or treating each other at the Booth.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

Well we have band stand & bands or sound cars and kitchens where meals are served. Ice cream & popcorn stand & new more liquor is on hand which spoils picnics now as we never had it then & no confusion in the old days.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

All took part.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

Just am not certain.

What year?

How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

1914

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
33. Describe any features or this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of games which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnic, family picnic, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drinks, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year?

How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 1931
Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?
Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? [Handwritten text not legible]
When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st). Both days

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)
[Handwritten text not legible]

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? Not many
What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? Not very often

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details. Some

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years? [Handwritten text not legible]

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates. Yes, now there's the travelling library book had in early days

48. Was there a school library? Yes When was it begun? 1910
To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home? All the books were read by people of district if they wanted them

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? We didn't very often
40. Then did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 1931
Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?
Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known
hockey, ball or other teams? Give names and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the
names and authors, or publishers, if known, as nearly as you can; how many
books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?
What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school?
Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? Yes. When was it begun? 1910
To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to
read at home? All the time he was read by people of all ages.

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading
material? Yes, almost every year.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? Yes
   When was it started? 1920
   Who started it? Am not sure
   Is it still in existence? Yes
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

One in the district looked after us at their home & kept records those who received them.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west? Farmer Advocate Family Herald - Free Press - Local Paper.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others. We still the Winnipeg Free Press and Herald - & Country Guide instead of Advocate Local Paper & added others since.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? No
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?
   Still have their Saturday Evening Post & newer ones.

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain. No as our relatives supplied us with plenty reading matter.
8.

50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? Yes

When was it started? 1946

Is it still in existence? Yes

If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contains, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, etc., and how arrangements were made for borrowing books.

One in the district library after we at Miss Home.

Rept. nearly 19

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the valley? (name, address, date)

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? Yes

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

Still have them

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain. No
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? Violin again.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Accordion, Violin.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them. Not any more.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe. We didn't have an organ, violin, autoharp, and mouth organ. An accordion, little harp.

In the community? (Were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe. Sometimes.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? Three leaves of shamrock, Wild Irish rose, Billy Dale, Clementine, Boy, best friend, his mother—German, another.

In the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain. Very much.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain. Yes, how do you songs.

63. Was there a band in your community? Yes. When was it started? Who started it? Carl Quisler. How long did it continue? Quite a few years. How many were in it? 20. Who was bandmaster? Carl Quisler. What instruments were included? Usual band instrument.

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for. Different events. Sports days, Picnics—Sort of uniforms, but fully.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? Violin, piano.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the West? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

In the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. Tell some of the favorite songs in the house? (Name of sheet music)

61. Was "folk music," or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or for some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? When was it started? Who started it? How many were in it? Who was conductor? What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where. If members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
10. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give name and dates and places of public appearances.

64. In music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HERBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

65. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, autographs, etc.? Explain.

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned.

(Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
Oxford
